video.title: Learn Java 8 - Full Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn Java 8 and object oriented programming with this complete Java course for beginners.

⭐️Contents ⭐️

⌨️ (0:00:00)  1 - Basic Java keywords explained
⌨️ (0:21:59)  2 - Basic Java keywords explained - Coding Session
⌨️ (0:35:45)  3 - Basic Java keywords explained - Debriefing
⌨️ (0:43:41)  4 - Packages, import statements, instance members, default constructor
⌨️ (0:59:01)  5 - Access and non-access modifiers
⌨️ (1:11:59)  6 - Tools: IntelliJ Idea, Junit, Maven
⌨️ (1:22:53)  7 - If/else statements and booleans
⌨️ (1:42:20)  8 - Loops: for, while and do while loop
⌨️ (1:56:57)  9 - For each loop and arrays
⌨️ (2:14:21)  10 - Arrays and enums
⌨️ (2:41:37)  11 - Enums and switch statement
⌨️ (3:07:21)  12 - Switch statement cont.
⌨️ (3:20:39)  13 - Logging using slf4j and logback
⌨️ (3:51:19)  14 - Public static void main
⌨️ (4:11:35)  15 - Checked and Unchecked Exceptions
⌨️ (5:05:36)  16 - Interfaces
⌨️ (5:46:54)  17 - Inheritance
⌨️ (6:20:20)  18 - Java Object finalize() method
⌨️ (6:36:57)  19 - Object clone method.      [No lesson 20]
⌨️ (7:16:04)  21 - Number ranges, autoboxing, and more
⌨️ (7:53:00)  22 - HashCode and Equals
⌨️ (8:38:16)  23 - Java Collections
⌨️ (9:01:12)  24 - ArrayList

🎥Course by Marcus Biel, an experienced software craftsman. Watch additional Java lessons from Marcus on his channel. Here is a link to watch the remaining episodes of the course: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VAPqQpWtMXU&list=PLFmkgh1ckFjH1LaQvs_5pAuaZVVZ_3qcM&index=25

🔗Check out a written version of this course with additional resources here: https://marcus-biel.com/java-beginner-course/

🔗Get even more Java resources from Marcus here: https://java8course.com 

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: panopticon
topLevelComment.text: I found this tutorial actually very useful for my specific purposes, but if you're a real beginner and wondering why everything is so cryptic, worry not: this isn't an actual beginner's tutorial, no matter what anyone says. You can't be expected to learn and understand test driven development and object oriented programming (all those keywords like public, private and classes etc.) without first getting familiar with the procedural aspects of a programming language. And even if you could, these hasty explanations would give you unnecessary stress. I'm not trying to diss the author, but this stuff just isn't presented in a beginner-friendly way. And btw, go check Caleb Curry if you're looking for something simpler to begin with.

topLevelComment.author: Kevin Brannen
topLevelComment.text:
Marcus,

It's 3 years later so you may never read this, but a few things about your video and course to help you with the next one…

First, thanks for doing this. I can tell it was a major effort to do it, edit it, etc, in order to make it all happen. Good job there!

I know it's may seem minor, but this char ";" is a semi-colon not a colon which looks like ":". Your continually saying "colon" when you mean "semi-colon" really threw me off at first.

This is not so minor. You tell us "just use a text editor", but then you don't do that, don't tell us what tool you are using, and you let the tool do a lot of things auto-magically. That means it's really really hard to reproduce what you're doing -- and during the first lesson. To make it worse, you're assuming a specific directory structure but spend only about 2 seconds showing us what that is, and don't show us the commands we should use to run it if we were using only a terminal and text editor like you suggested. Sorry, but that's a pretty major fail there when your students can't duplicate what you're dong. Please excuse my absence for a bit while I go find a tutorial about setting up a Java dev environment and probably a Makefile. I'll be back later...

topLevelComment.author: gogs008
topLevelComment.text: Firstly, Marcus, I super appreciate your 9 hour video course free to the masses! I think it's absolutely fantastic! 46:25 I thought objects/instances in Java are immutable. Mentioning that if a member variable of a class declared with the keyword "static" get's changed, it "updates" all other instances/objects of the class seems incorrect. Anyone wish to shed any light? Thanks!

replies.author: Kunal Singh
replies.text: it's correct. Static variables are associated with the class and not the object itself. That means that when you create a new object it does not create a copy of a static variable but has a reference to the original one created at class creation. So since all objects are referencing the same memory where a static variable is stored, as long as you change its value all objects will reflect that change.

Under 'src.Main.Java' (Directory), he's created a Java file called "PersonTest" 
You make a Java file by Right clicking the directory you want the file to be in, going to "new" and then "Java Class"

replies.author: s3babyy
replies.text:
When you're using a JDE (Java Development Enviroment), you need to create a project, That project can be called whatever you want as it wont really matter.
When you've done so and the project has loaded in, you should see your projects directory. Under your projects name there should be a "src" package (folder).
You can right click the "src" folder, go to 'new' click 'package'. This creates a new package (folder) in your project directory. 
What Marcus has done is he created a package under "src" and called it 'Main', and in 'Main', he created another package called 'Java'.
He's also created another package under "src" and called it 'Test', in which he created another package called 'Java'.
Under both Java packages he created another package called "com.marcusbiel.javacourse.lesson2", which is specifically for him as his domain is "com.marcusbiel".
You can call the package under 'Java' whatever you want, but if you're writing a code that you want to put out to the public, you're recommended to use a custom domain name.

Hope this helps. :)

topLevelComment.author: Sunny Hippies
topLevelComment.text:
This is good for me as a review but a little fast for actual beginners. 
If you were to attend university, the students would ask to slow down or you spend an hour in the lab just installing java and getting it to run
.
If this is truly for beginners then HE should start with installing Java and writing HEllo world in a text editor, then compile and run in command prompt.
 
Passing the string around with imported methods is pretty advanced for actual beginners. haha

I would include a very basic Pre-Chapter. Installing Java and running hello world in a text editor from CMD. Then  setting up an IDE and Saving the file system. 
If you do more of a slow install and start from real scratch, in a pre-chapter, then beginners will be less confused and you can get off and running with a more complicated way of doing, Hello World, which as you demonstrate, shows many Java features.

replies.author: Charlie Buttstink
replies.text: I'm still relatively new to Java. (speed) in this case is an integer variable. It's best to define the variable before using it in a method. For exampe, int speed = 10;       We define the variable before using it so that we can use it in more than just one method. For example, I can use the drive(speed) method, and I know that when I do so then whenever I call that method, the speed will ALWAYS be 10 because I've already defined it. On the other hand, I can create a NEW method called "walk". If I made a method like this:  walk(speed), I know that my walk speed will ALWAYS be 10 as well! Also, you cannot set a method's parameters using variables that you've defined within the method that you created them in. For example, if I wrote drive(speed) { int speed = 10; }, my drive method would not know that it has to look within itself to understand what the speed variable is. If I wrote it that way, the function of the drive method would simply be to MAKE the variable that I can use in another instance. So let's say I create the "drive" method without setting the parameter to speed, but I still create the speed variable within the method. drive() { int speed = 10; },  Then I made ANOTHER method and then I called the drive method within the second method, I suppose you could do it that way. That would be much more complicated in this usage of variables than setting the variable prior to creating any methods at all! If you're confused, just think of it like setting the physics of a world. You have to know the mechanics of friction before you create a functioning wheel! Therefore, you must set the value of friction first, then create your wheel.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mMu-JlBrYXo

Develop a simple OO Java application that makes use of an Array of Objects for a Vehicle System.
Keep the following information: VehicleID as a number, Make, Color, Selling Price as Double.
Your program should start with a menu. You may use a text based menu as follows:
1. Input Vehicle
2. List all Vehicles
3. Search a Vehicle
4. Exit
Input Vehicle will allow the user to input a number of vehicles. You may choose a fixed number or use a Sentinel Value to stop input.
List all Vehicles will list all vehicles inputted in the system.
Search a Vehicle will allow the user to input a VehicleID, and the system will perform a Linear Search and display the details of that vehicle.
The menu is inside a loop so that the program exits only when the user selects the Exit option.

topLevelComment.author: Mathew Robinson
topLevelComment.text: Is it frowned upon to have multi-level inheritance in Java? E.g. an Animal class, a Dog class that extends Animal, and a Puppy class that extends Dog?

replies.author: The Code Operative
replies.text: Not necessarily. It depends on your use case. However, most schools of though say to favor composition over inheritance. If there is shared functionality it should be contained in a separate class. Then, the classes that want to share those traits will have an instance of that class as a member variable.

topLevelComment.author: MyLOBsTerr
topLevelComment.text: For those who have problems with folder structure and who is a complete beginner. In the video he used IntelliJ IDEA. So, what you have to do. Go to File => Project structure => Modules. Click on "src" folder  and unset it as a Sources. Create a folder "main" and set it as Sources folder. Then create "test" folder  and set it as Tests folder. Then inside you can create you package structure. Good luck guys!

replies.text:
YOu have to be able to install Java, and Create package in an IDE like Eclipse or Netbeans. 
He says not to worry about the package import yet. 
This is a tad intermediate though. He doesn't explain how to set path so java can work from anywhere or how to use command prompts, he assumes you have some type of introductory knowledge. 
More of like a review of Java I. 
If you were to attend university, the students would slow him down and spend an hour in the lab installing java.
HE should start with installing Java and writing HEllo world in a text editor. 
Passing the string arround with imported methods is pretty advanced. haha
